planets.name: Moon
planets.description: Earth's natural satellite ‚Äî humanity's first foothold beyond our planet.

sites.name: Shackleton Crater
sites.description: Polar crater rim targeted by Artemis. Permanently shadowed ‚Äî ice confirmed. Rugged terrain, precise landing required.
sites.fun_fact: Contains water ice that may support future lunar bases!

sites.name: Shiv Shakti Point
sites.description: Historic landing site of India's Chandrayaan-3, first soft landing near the lunar south pole.
sites.fun_fact: India became the 4th nation to soft-land on the Moon here in August 2023!

sites.name: Tranquility Base
sites.description: Sea of Tranquility. Where Neil Armstrong took humanity's first steps on another world. Flat basaltic plains.
sites.fun_fact: The Eagle has landed! July 20, 1969 ‚Äî the most watched event in human history.

sites.name: Tycho Crater Floor
sites.description: One of the Moon's most prominent craters. Central peak rising 2km. Extremely challenging terrain.
sites.fun_fact: Tycho's bright rays extend over 1,500 km across the lunar surface!

planets.name: Mars
planets.description: The Red Planet ‚Äî next destination for human explorers. Thin atmosphere, ancient riverbeds, and towering volcanoes.

sites.name: Gale Crater
sites.description: Ancient lake bed selected for Curiosity. 154 km wide impact crater with stratified clay minerals confirming past water.
sites.fun_fact: Curiosity has driven over 30 km here since 2012, finding organic molecules!

sites.name: Jezero Crater
sites.description: Ancient river delta ‚Äî best place to look for signs of past microbial life. Rocky terrain with varied geology.
sites.fun_fact: Perseverance collected samples here that may be returned to Earth in the 2030s!

sites.name: Elysium Planitia
sites.description: Flat volcanic plains chosen for InSight's seismology mission. Perfect for precision landing ‚Äî minimal rocks.
sites.fun_fact: InSight detected over 1,300 marsquakes from this flat, quiet site!

sites.name: Olympus Mons Summit
sites.description: Summit of the solar system's tallest volcano at 25km altitude. Extreme winds, 0% survival probability.
sites.fun_fact: So tall it extends above Mars's atmosphere ‚Äî landing here is physically impossible!

sites.name: Valles Marineris Floor
sites.description: Floor of the solar system's largest canyon ‚Äî 7km deep walls create unpredictable turbulence. High-risk mission.
sites.fun_fact: Valles Marineris is as long as the United States is wide!

planets.name: Earth
planets.description: Home. SpaceX and private operators land rockets here routinely ‚Äî a new era of reusable spacecraft.

sites.name: CCAFS Landing Zone 1
sites.description: SpaceX's primary booster landing pad at Cape Canaveral, FL. Falcon 9 boosters return here after missions to ISS and commercial launches.
sites.fun_fact: The first successful Falcon 9 landing happened here on December 21, 2015!

sites.name: Pacific Ocean ASDS
sites.description: Just Read the Instructions ‚Äî SpaceX's Pacific drone ship. Autonomous landing on a moving platform at sea. Wind and waves make this extremely challenging.
sites.fun_fact: The drone ship can move to any location in the Pacific to catch a returning booster!

sites.name: Rocky Mountain Zone
sites.description: Hypothetical mountain landing ‚Äî thin air at altitude, powerful updrafts, precision critical. Not currently attempted.
sites.fun_fact: Colorado Rockies peak at 4,400m. Landing here would require extreme control!

sites.name: Everest Summit
sites.description: Summit of Earth's highest peak. Jet stream winds, 300mph gusts, extreme cold. 0% landing survivability.
sites.fun_fact: Winds at Everest's summit can reach 320 km/h ‚Äî faster than a bullet train!

planets.name: Titan
planets.description: Saturn's largest moon. Dense nitrogen atmosphere, methane lakes, and orange haze. A world unlike any other.

sites.name: Huygens Landing Site
sites.description: Where ESA's Huygens probe parachuted into Titan's thick orange atmosphere. Dense air actually aids descent! Like landing on a wind-swept beach.
sites.fun_fact: Huygens transmitted data for 72 minutes after landing on this alien world in 2005!

sites.name: Ligeia Mare Shore
sites.description: Shoreline of Titan's second-largest methane sea. NASA's Dragonfly rotorcraft will explore this region by 2034.
sites.fun_fact: Ligeia Mare is larger than Lake Superior ‚Äî filled with liquid methane at -179¬∞C!

planets.name: Asteroid Ryugu
planets.description: A spinning diamond-shaped asteroid 300 million km from Earth. Micro-gravity, ancient material from the dawn of our solar system.

sites.name: Sagamihara Site
sites.description: JAXA's touch-and-go sample collection site on Ryugu. Nearly zero gravity ‚Äî any excess speed causes bouncing into space.
sites.fun_fact: Hayabusa2 touched this surface for just 0.1 seconds to collect a 5.4g sample ‚Äî mission success!

planets.name: Venus
planets.description: Earth's twin turned hellscape. 465¬∞C surface, 90 atm pressure, sulfuric acid clouds. The ultimate challenge.

sites.name: Venera 7 Site
sites.description: Where Venera 7 survived for 23 minutes before being crushed by 93 atmospheres of pressure. Clouds of sulfuric acid, 465¬∞C surface.
sites.fun_fact: Venera 7 was the first spacecraft to return data from the surface of another planet ‚Äî 1970!

sites.name: Maxwell Montes Summit
sites.description: Summit of Venus's highest mountain at 11km ‚Äî still 460¬∞C. Crushing atmospheric pressure plus extreme terrain. 0% survivability.
sites.fun_fact: Even at Venus's highest point, the temperature is hot enough to melt lead!
